speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you first noticed that you hadn't started your period yet?

speaker: Patient
text: I remember it like it was yesterday, doc. I was around 12 or 13, and I just assumed I was late or something. But as the months went by and I still hadn't gotten my period, I started to get a bit worried.

speaker: Doctor
text: When was this first noticed, and how old were you at the time?

speaker: Patient
text: I was 12 years old when I first started to worry, and I had just turned 13 when I realized it was still not happening.

speaker: Doctor
text: So you first noticed the delay in your menarche when you were around 14 years old. That's a bit earlier than the average age for a girl to start menstruating, which is usually around 15. Can you tell me if you've noticed any other unusual physical changes or symptoms around that time?

speaker: Patient
text: Well, doc, around that time, I did notice that I had some extra hair growth on my chin, which was a bit embarrassing for me. I also had some acne that was pretty severe, and I was getting these really bad breakouts.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your overall health and well-being during that time - did you experience any other unusual symptoms, such as joint pain or fatigue?

text: Honestly, doc, I don't really remember experiencing any joint pain or fatigue back then. I just remember feeling a bit self-conscious about my acne and the hair growth on my chin, and it was really frustrating because I felt like I was different from my friends. I just tried to deal with it and hoped it would go away eventually.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the nature of the unusual physical changes you've experienced since then?

speaker: Patient
text: It's been a bit of a rollercoaster, to be honest. The acne has been really bad, especially during the times I was on oral isotretinoin. But it's been pretty manageable now that I'm on the oral contraceptive. As for the other physical changes, I've noticed that I have some... unusual growths, I guess you'd say, on my clitoris and labia. They've been there since birth, but they've just gotten a bit more noticeable as I've gotten older.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the nature of the unusual physical changes you've experienced since then?

speaker: Patient
text: It's just been really noticeable lately, especially when I'm getting ready for school or showering. They're a bit... prominent, I guess. And it's a bit embarrassing because I don't really know how to talk about them with anyone.

speaker: Doctor
text: So you said you've noticed other unusual physical changes. Can you tell me more about them? Are they related to your bones, such as any unusual breaks or fractures, or are they more about your joints or muscles?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, doc, I've had a pretty unusual history of fractures. I mean, I'm not talking about extreme trauma or anything, but I've broken bones just from minor stuff, like tripping over my own feet or falling off the couch. It's like my bones are really fragile or something.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your overall diet and lifestyle around the time your menarche was delayed? Have you noticed any changes in your eating habits or exercise routine that might be related to your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text:
To be honest, doc, I've always been pretty active, I guess. I play sports and stuff in school, but I don't really think that's related to my symptoms. As for my diet, I try to eat pretty healthily, but I do have a bit of a sweet tooth. I think I might have been eating more sugary snacks when I was younger, but I've been trying to cut back on that in recent years.

And I do remember that my mom was pregnant when I was born, and she had some pretty weird hair growth on her chin during that time. I don't know if that's related to anything, but it's definitely stuck with me.

speaker: Doctor
